Art. 4.41. 
Express or tacit acceptance 
Acceptance pure and simple may be express or tacit.
It is express when the successor assumes the title or capacity of heir in an authentic instrument or in an instrument under private signature.
It is tacit where the successor does an act which necessarily presupposes his intention to accept, and which he would be entitled to do only in his capacity as heir.
Acts of a purely conservatory nature, of supervision and of provisional administration, are not acts of acceptance of the succession, if the title or capacity of heir has not been assumed.
If, however, there are objects in the estate which are likely to deteriorate or which are expensive to keep, the successor may, without this being construed as acceptance, obtain judicial authorisation to sell these objects. The provisions of Book IV, Chapter V of the Judicial Code apply by analogy.
